column32: Relegated to technical support role in supposedly research position

One amendment--I would not say I was intimidated by the culture of criticism, I would say I was put off by it and felt that I did not need that kind of unnecessary stress in my life. I also note that the criticism culture is dominated and even shaped by the most societally privileged members of the field (white males from college-educated upper middle-class families). I come from a first-generation to college working class background. Why would I want to spend my life in uncivil intellectual tussles with those people. I left field just a few years ago and have never been happier.
column33: As clarification, I work with mostly privileged people in my profession now. They are not in and of themselves the problem. It's social psych's culture of sparring in a rigged contest. I'm totally over it.

column32: Although work/life balance and culture of criticism are extremely relevant, other extremely relevant points for me are not mentioned in the above list. These include: (1) the rise of despicable social media platforms such as Real Peer Review that belittle a range of academic work and do a disservice to the academy. There should be internal/external debate about research methods and approaches, but it should take place in a sober and extensive peer discussion, not a platform that mocks and belittles real people for their research interests and efforts. Frankly, it's disgusting, and contributes to the diminishment of academic research in the public sphere (and if academics are responsible for RPR and the like, they should be ashamed of themselves). (2) the attacks on academic freedom by the media and the like (at least in my location, Australia, but I'm sure it happens elsewhere), which also diminishes academic research in the public sphere. These points indicate a lack of proper, sober public debate about the value of research, and contribute to its diminishment. These are the main reasons I'd consider leaving. Why stay put when so much of your time is taken with looking over shoulder from attacks from the public, the media, or worse, other academics anonymously belittling other people's work (and who should know better)?
column33: I found your link via that disgusting platform Real Peer Review, which I see follows you. I don't know what your association with that shameful anti-academic platform is, but I hope you take a sober and critical view. These, again, are my comments ... column33: maybe just some closing thoughts: it was impossible for me to do research that A) I believed in B) that was robust (e.g. high statistical power, more likely to be replicable and C) publishable in top outlets. I felt at the time, and feel like this more and more, that the epistemology (requiring significant p-values from complicated studies (e.g. minimum of 2 X 2 designs) that are almost always underpowered, building up a series of experiments where the effects are teased apart in ways which I now see are statistically unbelievable...) is a dead end. In other words- if you really believed in getting solid answers to the questions you're asking as an academic social scientist, you would *never* go about your work in the way that is typical in psychology. I'm a "data scientist" now, and for all the crap that comes along with it, I never worry about sample size or making tenuous inferences from poor data. It makes an enormous difference in how I feel about my work.

column32: I find that the pressure to publish undermines my ability to think creatively and pursue the questions actually worth pursuing.  I find that self-employment (actually:  starting a technological company) affords me this precious freedom.  The academic institutions I've encountered do more to stifle innovation and discovery than to foster it.  They incentivize working on easy problems that guarantee publication, whereas, counter-intuitively, a capitalistic career enables me to pursue my intellectual interests once my basic needs are met.  This is the primary reason for my departure.  In less than 6 months I had a living wage, and I have two days per week devoted to my own personal projects/edification.
column33: This is very important work you're doing, so thank you!  I really wanted to enjoy academia, but it was one of the most suffocating environments I've ever encountered.

In terms of funding, incentives, and recognition by peers, it seems like academia is often a game. If you have particular attributes (prestigious mentors, networking skills, etc.) you can game the system. Related to this, the researcher/journal name-dropping culture (e.g. "I just got published in PSYCH SCI with *insert famous researcher*") is incredibly unscientific and irritating.

The acronym "QRPs" used in one of the questions was not a familiar acronym to me and I had to google what it meant. Consider writing out the word rather than using the acronym.     I also think that the current job categories listed on the first page aren't similar enough in scope to allow some respondents to accurately pick one. I work as a researcher at a non-profit research organization doing mostly psychology-related work (but some not-really-psychology-related research too). I picked that I was working in psychology, but a category like "industry" would have applied too. "Industry" and "government" are sectors, but some of the other categories were topic areas that can be worked on within those sectors.

column32: I do not like that academics look down on students who choose applied psychology career paths and both explicitly and implicitly discourage them from leaving academia

There are many MANY other factors contributing to this issue. I have been offered 3 post docs in, what I would consider, amazing departments. The problem is, they are merely postdocs. Tenure track positions now require you to remain a poor individual (literally) until well into your 30s. At which time if you get a tenure position you aren't paid nearly enough to stay out of debt. Not only this, but in some cases the academic is pigeon holed by working with certain researchers for highly specialized skills that do not translate into anything but the academy. This results in a huge disconnect with the pace of science and technology happening in real time. Some of the best work is no longer being done in the academy but "out there" in industry where the real data (in real time) is being collected and analyzed. I have also seen grants being won by underserving scientists and that money be poorly managed, or incentivized in awful ways. It's systemic. If you're looking at it from the inside, wondering why people don't stay in it, you've isolated yourself from the problem. Specifically, "why did you leave academia" is a question that suggests there's US and THEM - those that leave and those that stay in. You're missing the mark - it's not about us/them industry is not a blackbox of scary "working people". Get out. See for yourself, then blur the gap between industry and academia, Sit on the fence and connect the two.
column33: There are many MANY other factors contributing to this issue. I have been offered 3 post docs in, what I would consider, amazing departments. The problem is, they are merely postdocs. Tenure track positions now require you to remain a poor individual (literally) until well into your 30s. At which time if you get a tenure position you aren't paid nearly enough to stay out of debt. Not only this, but in some cases the academic is pigeon holed by working with certain researchers for highly specialized skills that do not translate into anything but the academy. This results in a huge disconnect with the pace of science and technology happening in real time. Some of the best work is no longer being done in the academy but "out there" in industry where the real data (in real time) is being collected and analyzed. I have also seen grants being won by underserving scientists and that money be poorly managed, or incentivized in awful ways. It's systemic. If you're looking at it from the inside, wondering why people don't stay in it, you've isolated yourself from the problem. Specifically, "why did you leave academia" is a question that suggests there's US and THEM - those that leave and those that stay in. You're missing the mark - it's not about us/them industry is not a blackbox of scary "working people". Get out. See for yourself, then blur the gap between industry and academia, Sit on the fence and connect the two.     I could go on and on and on. Also - I think you should make this survey open ended. There's a hell of a lot that's not captured by your questions.

column33: I'm an odd case in that I intended both to leave academia and to switch fields, but the first job I found in the new field (statistics) was (non-TT) academic; then I did leave academia, but came back to it at a higher rank, still in statistics. So a couple of your questions were an odd fit for me. I don't know what your research question is but if some qualitative info on this career path is of use to you, you can contact me at emjonaitis at gmail dot com.

column33: Was recently told that if I wanted to stay in academia I'd have to be willing to move anywhere. With over a dozen publications (all but two first or second author) in my final year of grad school, I know I could easily get a great post doc then a TT job-- but I'm NOT willing to move anywhere. I value being close to family, and living in a place my partner will like. I also value living in a place that is queer friendly and welcoming to interracial couples. So I'll apply to Tenure Track jobs, but also other jobs in areas I want to live in. My reason has 0 to do with QRPs
